dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COSTELLO's profile passes in a dark room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Years ago, we had the Church. That was only a way of saying we had each other. The Knights of Columbus were head-breakers. They took over their piece of the city.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The neighborhood. 1980's. We won't be here long. This isn where Costello ends up. It's where he began. Liquor store with shamrocked signs. MEN FISHING near Castle Island. Catholic SCHOOLKIDS playing in an asphalted schoolyard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty years after an Irishman couldn't get a job, we had the presidency. That's what the niggers don't realize. If I got one thing against the black chaps it's this. No one gives it to you. You have to take it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COSTELLO comes in. The shop is one that sells papers, sundries, fountain drinks...and fronts a bookie operation

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (leaning over cluttered counter) Don't make me have to come down here again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Won't happen again, Mr. C.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The frightened proprietor hands over money. Fifty bucks, hundred, doesn't matter. COSTELLO is never the threatener His demeanor is gentle, philosophical. Almost a shrink's probing bedside manner. He has great interest in the worl as he moves through it. As if he originally came from a different world and his survival in this one depends on c continual observation and analysis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: YOUNG COLIN looks up. CLOSE ON his eyes. He is fourteen o fifteen, but small for his age. Bookish.

dialogues.text: To you, O Lord we commend the soul of Alphonsus, your Servant; in the sight of this world he is now dead; in your sight may he live forever. Forgive whatever sins he committed through human weakness and in your goodness grant him everlasting peace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.text: COLIN sits on a bench looking at THE GOLD DOME OF BEACON HILL. The terraces of fine townhouses. Aqueous golden lig behind. Misty golden beauty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you looking at? Forget it. Your father was a janitor, and his son's only a cop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not vainglorious, but innocently stretching for the idea) You're in trouble if you're "only" anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't tell me I'm looking at the first dickhead-American president of the United States.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COLIN doesn't have a great sense of humor but he knows ho pretend that he does. He smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bagpipes and bullshit. Flags cracking. Line after line of paramilitary-looking graduates, among them COLIN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Massachusetts State Police has a long tradition of excellence. Your graduation today solidifies your acceptance into one of the finest law enforcement agencies in our nation. As the Governor of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts, I am confident each and every one of you will serve with distinction, honor and integrity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA swirls around COLIN as he moves, a lone person, through the breaking up crowd. Other graduates are hugged family. COLIN, alone, comes to the gates of the yard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Congratulations. You are dismissed.

dialogues.text: COLIN walks over to the car. COSTELLO gives COLIN a BOX. COLIN flips open the top and then quickly closes it. NOTE The box could contain an eyeball, money, drugs, a picture Colin fucking his school teacher...we will never know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: School's out. You earned it. Yeah, no more teachers, no more books.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (exasperated by this) To where. (Yeah)

dialogues.text: This is not the regular police. This is the state police. Your training will illustrate the difference. What's the difference?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A BLACK-WINDOWED, MODERN, POLICE BUILDING, beetling over plaza. Older Boston reflected in the featureless glass. T Boston of this film is almost futuristic. COLIN looks up the building with great intensity. He puts on his sunglas and walks towards the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COLIN, in civvies (a very good suit), stands at suave attention before CAPTAIN QUEENAN, a mild and scholarly ma who might as well be a Jesuit history-teacher.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Congratulations on passing the detective exam, and welcome to the Special Investigation Unit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tonelessly) Whoop-di fuckin' do.

dialogues.text: We won't be working directly together, you'll be working for Captain Ellerby, but I like to see everybody. (contemplating him) You're a worker, you rise fast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like a twelve year old's dick. (Alt: Like a turd in the pool.)

dialogues.text: Thank you, Sergeant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Queenan) Thank you, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As COLIN leaves the office, looking very satisfied and no little saturnine (it's not as if he isn't pleased by recognition and it's not as if he won't get revenge on Dignam), he barely glances--and does not actually see--th TRAINEE sitting off to one side. He sees polished brogues and walks on.

dialogues.text: (whispering, joyful, in love with COLIN) Congratulations.

dialogues.text: Thanks, hon.

dialogues.text: As COLIN leaves she moderates her expression and:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.text: BILLY looks up. He has not seen COLIN, and COLIN has not him. He has his interview on his mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So.

dialogues.text: BILLY has no idea why he is in this room with the brass. Sgt. Dignam is staring at him aggressively, with contempt stirring his coffee. DIGNAM is more intelligent than he seems.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know what we do here?   My section?

dialogues.text: BILLY doesn't want to answer unless he can answer correct

dialogues.text: Whoa, let's say you have no idea and leave it there. No idea. Zip, none. If you had an idea about what we do we would not be good at what we do. We would be cunts. Are you calling us cunts?

dialogues.text: BILLY wouldn't normally take crap from this guy; but he d He's openly intrigued by the situation. Dignam is staring him. BILLY looks evenly at QUEENAN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (getting to business, hard) You have family connections down in Southie. Through your father. Tell us about your uncle Jackie.

dialogues.text: Uncle Jackie was a small-time bookie who tended bar at the Vets in Somerville.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He got popped by Nicastro in '95. They found his body out by the airport.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY says slowly:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right. (tightly) I remember his funeral.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cruelly) Closed casket?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You tell anybody at Deerfield - that is, before you got kicked out for whaling on a gym teacher with a folding chair - you had an uncle met his demise like that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got a question. How fucked up are you?

dialogues.text: COLIN, in his good suit, moves along the hall. He owns th building. He looks into offices. He is looking at his fut From one room BARRIGAN (still working in uniform) gives h the thumbs up. COLIN gets a coffee. He looks at a secreta ass. Caught at it, he smiles beautifully. She smiles back

dialogues.text: What you got? (with admiration and envy) "Staff Sergeant". In four years you're a sergeant.

dialogues.text: SIU. What a country.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meaning to some extent "Perfect for a dick like you". Thi how friends come apart. BARRIGAN is unable to continue hi pose of congratulation. COLIN (close on Colin) is on to h

dialogues.text: I know you're a worker. I might be able to do something for you. You got any suits at home or you like coming to work looking like you're gonna invade Poland.

dialogues.text: What's this got to do with me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This unit is new, and you are the newest members of it. You have been selected for it on the basis of intelligence and aptitude.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is an elite unit. Our job is to smash--or at least marginally disrupt-- (he gets the laugh he expected) --organized crime in this city by our own efforts and by enhanced cooperation with the FBI, represented here by Agent Frank Lazio-- (show the deeply unreliable dandy LAZIO) and we will do it. And by organized crime in this city...you know who we mean.

Lifers down there. Three decker men at best. You grew up, however, up the North shore. La di (fuckin') da.

dialogues.text: You were kind of a double kid, I bet, right? One kid with your old man. One kid with your mother. Upper middle class in the week, and then dropping your 'r's and hanging in the Southie projects with daddy the donkey on the weekends. I got that right?

dialogues.text: BILLY, opened up expertly and crudely, stares with contai hatred.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have different accents? You did, didn't you. (You little fuckin' snake.) You were different fuckin' people.

dialogues.text: You a psychiatrist?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I was I'd ask you why you're a Statie making thirty grand a year. And I think if I were Sigmund fucking Freud himself I wouldn't get an answer. So tell me, what's a lace curtain motherfucker like you doing in the Staties?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well. Families are always rising or falling in America. Am I right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (appreciative, kindly, looking up from his papers) Who said that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hawthorne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SGT. DIGNAM (although he knows perfectly well who Hawthor is) makes a fart-noise with his mouth. BILLY looks at him with an "I'm going to kill you" expression which is not without wit and which Dignam seems to admire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter, smartass? You don't know any fuckin' Shakespeare?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have a question. You want to be a cop, or do you want to appear to be a cop. It's an honest question. Lot of guys want to appear to be cops. Gun. Badge. Pretend they're on TV...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lot of em just want to slam a nigger's head through a plate glass window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm all set without your personal job application, Sergeant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a "we got a live one" glance at Queenan) What the fuck did you say to me, trainee?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY looks at him, and then looks forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, with all due respect, sir, what is it you want from me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey asshole, he can't help you. I know what you are, and what you aren't. I'm the best friend you ever had on the face of the earth. I'm gonna help you understand something: You're no fuckin' cop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's right. (Billy looks at Queenan) We deal in deceptions here. But what we don't deal with is self- deception. In five years, you might be anything else in the world, but you won't be a Massachusetts State trooper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sure of that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure of that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guaranteed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking up from his papers) You don't have much family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (deciding this on the spot) I don't have any family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A TROLLEY goes past. HOSPITAL HILL, above the trolley lin is sinister, quiet. HOSPITAL at the top like a malign fortress, above rows of endlessly repeated condominiums. BILLY CROSSES from the Trolley stop, desperately, an angr young man at his life's turning point.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY'S MOTHER lies as if floating in her bed. Tubes, lig A bald head on a barely-dented pillow. She is a cancer patient in a coma, weighing possibly 80 lbs. Gasping for Her airways are cleared with a suction tube. BILLY sits watching as the tube goes in. BILLY sits looking at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY is leaning against a wall. A maternal WASP UNCLE, a bright guy (pretensions, rather than status), speaks brie to a DOCTOR further along the hall, then approaches BILLY hands in the pocket of a good suit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's this I hear from Stephanie about you becoming a policeman?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean Stephanie who was the only one who came to my father's funeral? That Stephanie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That Stephanie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing much to it Uncle Edward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you trying to prove something to the family?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you say "family", what do you mean? You?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You always question everything, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, maybe it would have done you some good to have a question from time to time. "Am I an asshole?" "Are my kids a mess?" "Is my wife a money-grubbing whore?" Those are questions. (the UNCLE starts to leave) "Have I been good to my dying sister or am I just pretending to be?" (he's stung THE UNCLE) Too late now, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you need some money for the funeral?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE UNCLE moves away, bends to get his overcoat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When my mother dies we don't have any connection. You got it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AERIAL. FLY FROM the HOSPITAL TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A REALTOR switches on lights. An empty, flash apartment a the Parisian rooftops of Beacon Hill. A view of the Dome. More than you'd think a cop could afford. We see, as COLI does, beyond his reflection in the glass, the STATE HOUSE DOME.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is it. Nice. You've got high ceilings, parquet floors. There's a lock on the fridge in case you have eating issues.... Joke...not a very good one. (uneasy) So, you're a policeman?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (like something he is used to reciting) I'm a State Police detective.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wondering where he gets his money from) State Police Detective. You a married State Police Detective?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coming out of his reverie and coldly:) ...No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, cuz it's big and I wondered if a cop...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a cosigner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You intend to have a housemate. That's cool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give me the fuckin' papers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY sits on a bench looking out over the whole city. (I the best view of Boston, never seen in a film). He's smok a cigarette, making his decision.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Continuation of the interview.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what do I do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: During the war, Churchill used river mines. He'd float them down the rivers into Germany. They'd either hit something, or not. That's what we'll use you for. I'll float you down the river. The rest will happen. Or it won't... (a beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By the way, this isn't police work for peanuts. There's money behind this operation. You won't be paid as a cop, but there is a bonus involved. Tax free.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: QUEENAN writes on a slip of paper and hands it to BILLY. BILLY looks up from the paper, impressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luck of the Irish. All that and you're still young enough to fuck undergraduates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can't conceal that you've been a trainee. You'll be convicted of a crime. We're thinking that a guilty plea to assault and battery might make sense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Given your nature.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll serve enough jail time to convince anyone that it's no set- up. You'll be on probation. The whole nine yards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need you, pal. You've already pretended to be a Costigan from South Boston.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY looks up with a glazed insolence. In one beat he is a scared trainee but a smart criminal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every weekend...Sergeant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perfect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do it again. For me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY throws down his cigarette. He has decided.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Priest's cassock whipping in the wind. A few mourners (sh genteel ladies, contemporaries of his mother), but Billy seems to have no real connection with any of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY is alone at the grave. He looks at the tags on wind blown wreaths. One gives him pause. Under a picture of Th Virgin it reads: "Heaven holds the Faithful Departed" and signed: "F. Costello".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A CELL DOOR CLOSES. On Billy. Looking like a real crimina Not a pretend one. Frightened and resolute at once. BILLY in a holding tank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COLIN, in a bathrobe, leans on the rail and looks at Bost THE GOLD DOME visible. Colin drinks coffee. Not satisfied worried.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY, naked, holds his clothes in a bundle. Being proces out of jail. Beside him another guy, furtive, gruff, not trying to be friendly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're Bill Costigan?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who wants to know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothin.' I know a Sean Costigan. L Street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My cousin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Connected but not too bright-- (BILLY looks at him with an only-I-can-insult-my- cousin look) No offense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy gets his clothes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the wall is a rogues gallery of COSTELLO and all his primary guys...MISTER FRENCH, DELAHUNT, FITZY. COLIN and others sitting listening. COLIN, reading a paper (Boston Herald) which may or may not have the headline, CASE DROP AGAINST DRUGS CADET (featuring a picture of Billy), looks as SGT. DIGNAM comes in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry I'm late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Staff Sergeant Dignam is our liaison with the undercover section. Their undercover work is extensive. He's here to give us his report. Sgt. Dignam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK. They're out there, my people. They're like the fuckin' Indians. You're not gonna see them. You're not gonna hear about them except through me or Captain Queenan. You will not, ever, know the identity of undercover people. This shit hole, unfortunately, has more fuckin' leaks than the Iraqi navy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm tired from fucking your wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's your mother?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. She's tired from fucking my father. (opens a FILE) OK, today, girls, what I got for you is microprocessors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LAZIO, the Fed, comes in and sits down. With folders, pen

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somebody, as you may already know, stole one hundred microprocessors from the Mass Processor Corp out Route 128. They're the kind of processors they put into computers that can put a cruise missile up the ass of a camel from the other side of the planet. That's what they do out there on "America's Technology Highway". Worth a hundred grand apiece. Guy worked for the company two months walked out the door with a box of processors on Tuesday, has a ticket booked for Florida on Wednesday, but on Thursday he gets found in a dumpster. You know where this dirt ball started his life? Southie projects.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was his name? The, ah, departed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Myles Kennefick. Got the job with a forged UMass transcript. UMass Boston, which incidentally happens to be in...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: South Boston?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who forged your transcript, dickhead?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know that guy. His father runs the Hibernian Liquor Mart. Kennefick's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are not here to solve the "Case of the Dead Scumbag". We are here to nail Costello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COLIN stands down, embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We got a guy says that   he hears Costello is moving the   processors to China...that he set   up the whole fuckin' job and popped   Kennefick. (LAZIO is writing, lawyerish.) You don't want to miss   it if Costello takes a dump.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'd miss less if your informants were available to us, and of course to the FBI (Bureau)...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Without asking for details, do you have anyone in with Costello presently?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe. Maybe not. Maybe fuck yourself. My theory on Feds is they're like mushrooms. Feed 'em shit and keep in the dark. You girls have a nice day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY steps off a bus at a corner. He goes up to a house, knocks on the door. A Southie hag answers. On an oxygen cylinder, smoking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aunt Cathy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His aunt takes her cigarette out of her mouth and then embraces him fiercely. BILLY takes it like the imposter h is. But he might well love his aunt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good to see you. Good to see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY is eating soup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They said you were in the Staties, I couldn't believe it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got kicked out about four months ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was in the papers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sean is a villain leaning in a doorway. Bad tie: he takes off. He has been at a funeral.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well. So you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And why are we graced with your presence?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I brought your mother some pictures of my father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's true. They are on the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My mother had them. My mother's dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reflexively) I'm sorry. I'm sorry for your troubles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sean opens the fridge, opens a beer, and hands it to BILL He opens one for himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was at a funeral myself. Myles Kennefick, knew him in school. Beat the fuck out of him seven or eight times as a matter of fact. (affably to Billy) You workin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sean and BILLY are still drinking beer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When did I see you after that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not for a long time. Down the cape after Rose's wedding. I think.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck, oh shit. I remember that, dude. I had that fuckin' buck knife, right, and I cut all the brass numbas off the doors at the hotel. I was trippin'...All of them. That was a night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sean looks deflated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, I got twenty thousand dollars when my mother died. Insurance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In your line of work, if I gave you ten thousand dollars what could you give me back?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My line of work... I'm not in that line of work just presently because I don't have ten thousand dollars. As a matter of fact I have never had ten thousand dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what I'm saying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sean nods, and nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what we usually say at these moments.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You fuckin' moron. What are you talking about? I'm not a cop. I'm your cousin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY is waiting. Sean comes out of a squalid looking hou and gets into a car. Fast. Billy puts the car in gear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuckin' Ricans think they know everything. If they knew shit they wouldn't be Puerto Ricans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He has a paper bag full of money. He opens a beer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (high as a kite) Double the money, double the fun. (confusing his TV jingles) Cinnamon toasty apple bun... R is for Ricans...P is for pigs...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They drive past a BPD cruiser. Sean hides his beer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't stop drinkin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why would you even think of stopping drinking?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He don't like it. He don't like drinkin...he don't like fightin... (Sean looks sad) ...he says stay out of the bars... You know, we're not even supposed to do this on this side of fuckin' Worcester.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who says?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He says. Costello says. God says, as far as you're concerned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sean, beyond wasted, is talking to some people, including MISTER FRENCH. A table wet with spilled beer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not a cop. He got out of the joint three weeks ago. Dead up. He talks like his shit don't stink but he's good people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cunt cop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew his father. I liked his uncle Jackie better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uncle Jackie was excellent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fucking guineas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They solemnly toast uncle Jackie and his fate among the fucking guineas. Across the crowded room, BILLY is orderi at the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cranberry juice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a natural diuretic. My girlfriend drinks it when she got her period. (to BILLY) You got your period?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY glances over at the table where MISTER FRENCH sits SEAN, and then smashes his glass into the face of the WEL DRESSED SCUMBAG. He stands waiting for the SCUMBAG to get he is grabbed and shoved against the wall by MISTER FRENC Popped into a pay phone hard. The pay phone comes off the hook.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get your hands off me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY shakes his head no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm the guy who tells you there are guys you hit and there are guys you don't. That's not quite a guy you can't hit, but it's almost a guy you can't hit, so I'm fucking ruling on it right now that you don't hit him, understand?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Excellent. Fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know you. I know your family. Also I know you do another drug deal with your idiot fucking cop- magnet cousin I'll forget your grandmother was very nice to me and cut your fucking nuts off. You understand that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now you know me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat: they stare at each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you drinking?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cranberry juice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it, your period?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get him a cranberry juice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The WELL-DRESSED SCUMBAG is bleeding, incredulous. MISTER FRENCH takes him by the shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sotto voce to WELL- DRESSED SCUMBAG) That's Jackie's nephew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRENCH demolishes him with body blows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get the fuck out of here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COLIN and BARRIGAN (who Colin has moved to plain clothes) stand at the door, talking, or trying to talk, with a fea MRS KENNEFICK. MRS KENNEFICK looks like she starts drinki whiskey at 9 in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Kennefick, Myles and I were in school together. Myles was behind me in school but I knew him. I will get those responsible. Don't you want to see us catch whoever used him to do a robbery and then killed him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Allegedly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grimaces) "Allegedly".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If he was killed he probably did something wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't mean robbery do you, Mrs Kennefick? That's not what you think he did wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS. KENNEFICK notices COSTELLO driving by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Costello and Gwen are in the car.    Gwen is dressed like Jackie O.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wave to your girlfriend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean fuck yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She slams the door. As COLIN walks away from the door he notices the TAIL: a maroon sedan and a damaged white deli van.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You get that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Allegedly" or "fuck yourself?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welcome to the neighborhood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FRENCH pulls up to a light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: [COSTELLO blows a red light and leaves the tail (includin the Surveillance Van which we will see again) behind him snarl of traffic.]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cut 'em here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: French steps on it and blows through the light, leaving t follow cars behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bye, bye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COLIN boards with a bunch of other cops and workers. On board, directly beside him, is MADOLYN. COLIN's age, beautiful, wearing a business suit. She has a thick stack medical-looking files. She's a psychiatrist on contract t the Commonwealth of Massachusetts. She does probation counselling work with "violent offenders" and also sees policemen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Making a house call?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have I seen you professionally?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no. I know what you do. I know who you are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MADOLYN nods, and then because this is a (relatively) sensitive subject ignores COLIN, but she is visibly attra by him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When guys have to "use their "service revolvers" in the "course of duty" they get to talk to you about their "feelings" and whatnot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MADOLYN laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Oh, I know how it goes. You're a mental health professional.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughing) I have an appointment on this floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door opens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's good. They're all fuckin' crazy on that floor. (points up) I'm one floor up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, fancy policeman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right. Fancy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you a Statie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After she steps out he prevents the door from closing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I'm also getting my law degree.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suffolk, nights?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They don't run Harvard Law at night, last time I checked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When was the last time you checked?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before I went to fucking Suffolk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I went to U Mass. I wasn't insulting you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well I thought you were, and for that you have to take me to dinner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe you could shoot someone and I'd have to see you professionally.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatever it takes. I'll stab someone in the heart with an icepick right now if it gets me dinner with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MADOLYN hands him a card.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't need a card, I'm a detective.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hesitates. He takes the card.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm only joking. Nice to meet you... "Madolyn".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doors close. The elevator takes him up. He takes out cellphone as if he's forgotten something. As the doors op the signal bars light up, and the phone rings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (walking, voice low) I didn't know about your tail until I saw it myself. I couldn't call, I had the other guy with me. Blue sedan and a white delivery van, fucked up with graffiti on the side. The van is audio surveillance. OK, have a nice day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The same shop in which YOUNG COSTELLO talked to YOUNG COL all those years ago. Two ITALIANS are in the shop, talkin hard to the Pakistani PROPRIETOR (SINGH). These are hard but they're not being threatening, just persistent: the g DOES owe them money. BILLY is finishing his breakfast. Watching. He goes over. The two GUINEAS are amazed. [Dial on separate document].

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy is finishing his breakfast. Watching. He goes over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You guys from Providence?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The GUINEAS look at him. The younger one moves to interve BILLY smiles and destroys them both. Maniacal violence. T biggest beatdown in gangster movie history--and obviously that's saying something. In the course of the beat-down B breaks his left hand--a "boxer's fracture". BILLY stands his victims, breathing hard, holding his broken hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What have you done to my place! Get out of here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY goes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY, unlit cigarette in his mouth, is having his hand wrapped in plaster by a lady doctor. In another life he m have dated her. Not in this one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A romantic restaurant. The best Boston has (which isn't saying much, but whatever). COLIN, looking great, a man o the rise. MADOLYN in pearls, also looking great. But mayb the conversation has lapsed and the date gone south.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You also do probation work, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right. I see "violent offenders".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad guys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's one way to look at it.   Not necessarily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COLIN wonders if she's breaking his balls. A DESSERT arri some towering Japanesey concoction with a fan of sugar ca spines, sitting in a pool of sauce. COLIN looks at it, fo poised. MADOLYN looks at it. He looks up at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That have this and they don't have duck l'orange.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MADOLYN smiles: she likes him. Even with the dinner-long bitterness over the duck l'orange.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was your dinner OK?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (holding balloon of inappropriate wine) Oh, the lobster was excellent. I just thought, French restaurant...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The look at the dessert.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm waiting for you to make your move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what you're gonna do, but if it moves I'm going to arrest it (shoot it).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MADOLYN laughs.    COLIN sees his shot: he's got her laug

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's it like having people "find themselves?" All day long people "finding themselves." Does it get messy with all those feelings flying around the room?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, does that make you uncomfortable?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colin stares at her.    Water glass nearly goes over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what Freud said about the Irish?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you actually do I'll see you again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who says I want to see you again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (concerned, perhaps unexpectedly) Don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, course I do. (a beat) What Freud said about the Irish is We're the only people impervious to psychoanalysis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MADOLYN is impressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tough luck for you with a client list of Mick cops, isn't it. "Opening up"? Good luck to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COLIN laughs but looks nervous about the concept of "open up".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you do it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some people do get better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COLIN takes it seriously; admires it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fair enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes, though, I want people to forget about their personal bullshit and do their jobs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unsaid: Like I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Including the criminals?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If they don't do their jobs you don't have one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me? I'd just arrest innocent people. I'll arrest you right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're trouble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't know the half of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A slow night. BILLY IS AT THE BAR bent over a glass of cranberry juice. The women available are two CRONES. [Dia on separate document]. Stark contrast to COLIN'S EVENING. BOOKMAKER on the phone. BILLY, by the glances of people looking at him, has made his bones. He's treated with respect. His hand and wrist in a cast. Out of nowhere (th Billy is aware conversation has stopped he does not look around)...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COSTELLO sits down beside him AT THE BAR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY observes:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MISTER FRENCH sitting down at a far table. Watching. Cove the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COSTELLO is brought a glass of water by the silent barten No sound whatsoever in the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They say nothing, look at each other. BILLY notices DELAH and FITZY, entering. They stand by MISTER FRENCH.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY sits motionless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know who I am?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY does: but shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You met my friend, Mister French the other night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is his real name Mister French?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. (a beat) Come with me. (As BILLY hesitates) I'm not the cops. I'm not askin' you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY stands up. MISTER FRENCH stands up. BILLY, COSTELLO and MISTER FRENCH move towards the back room. As they wal the back room of the bar, we hear COSTELLO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know something, they just do not stop having the Mafia in Providence, and this can cause problems for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those guys you tuned up are connected down Providence. What they're going to do is come back up with some guys and kill you. Which, sure as you're born, they will do unless I stop them. Do you want me to stop them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it something I can't do personally?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COSTELLO appreciates the balls of this. He looks at Miste French. Then back at Billy, smiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to have my associate search you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY tenses. Exactly as he might if he were wearing a wi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Search me? Search me for what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MISTER FRENCH and COSTELLO look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'm here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Contra-fucking-band.    Take your fuckin' shoes off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shoes off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY slips out of them. MISTER FRENCH inspects the shoes COSTELLO'S cold eyes are on BILLY. MISTER FRENCH searches BILLY. Looks into his wallet. The wallet is emptied onto table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew your father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. He's dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.     How did he go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He didn't complain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was his problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who said he had a fuckin' problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just said he had a fuckin' problem. There's a man could have been anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you saying he was nothing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm saying he worked at the airport.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COSTELLO turns to MISTER FRENCH.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's clean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With amazing violence MISTER FRENCH smashes the cast on t corner of a table. Billy drops to his knees in tears of p MISTER FRENCH sorts through the pieces of the cast. Ad li "such a fuckin' pussy."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (holding Billy by the collar) It makes me curious to see you in this neighborhood. Regressing. And, if I can slander my own formative environment, it makes me sad, this regressing. Plus, I don't know if it's beyond some cop prick like fucking Queenan to pull you out of the Staties, and send you after me. I just can't know. I don't know what they do in...that department, anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He grabs Billy's broken right hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you still a cop?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COSTELLO twists Billy's broken hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You swear on your mother's grave that you're not a cop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am not a cop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You stop doing coke deals with your jerk-off cousin?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COSTELLO lets go of Billy's hand. Billy is weeping on the floor. COSTELLO straightens his suit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take it easy. Get your hand taken care of. I'm sorry. It was necessary. As for our problem with Providence...let's not cry over spilled guineas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COSTELLO, the visiting king, points at a group of drinker including a BLOND WOMAN (1st), GWEN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's this IRA motherfucker doing in my bar?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The IRA MOTHERFUCKER is terrified.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slapping him on the back) Only kidding. How's your mother?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, she's on her way out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We all are. (straightens suit and tie) Act accordingly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Costello exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MISTER FRENCH is methodically shelling and eating peanuts

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you trust him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These days, who's reliable?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His Uncle Jackie was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Costigans are talented in general.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't trust a guy behaves like he's got nothin' to lose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm reliable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you're one in a million.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ten million.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about your wife?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought she was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She wasn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SILENT FLASH of MISTER FRENCH strangling his wife with a in a 70's bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She got reliable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GWEN looks up:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you people ever shut the fuck up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Another county heard from."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One too many.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SEAGULLS squabble over unusual food. POWER PLANT IN THE DISTANCE, the MTA-train going by. TWO BODIES lie in a tid ditch in the salt-marsh. They are the Italians who Billy fought in the restaurant. Hands taped together behind the backs. Two in the head each. COLIN is with the LYNN POLIC and the State Police forensics people. COLIN gets down an lifts a soaking lapel. Revealed is the tag of a men's sho Providence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The principles of detection tell me that these men came from Providence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd appreciate it if you got out of my crime scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is my crime scene, but knock yourself out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COLIN gets up. He walks back across the marsh. Opens his phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (walking) I saw a dead guy. I think I have post traumatic stress. You available for lunch? See you then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At a PAY PHONE he dials another number.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of Costello's homes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's the lead detective?...Good, he's a moron.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY cannot hear what COSTELLO is saying. He has an alum brace taped on his wrist and hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want you to get the cops to look at Jimmy Pappas for the hit. Of course he had nothing to do with it and will say so. You look in

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: his car...and find...the gun that did it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the trunk or the glove box?... All right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COLIN deadpan, appreciative, hangs up the phone. BARRIGAN walks in the middle distance, giving the man his privacy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wanna see some dead guys?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COSTELLO sits down in the breakfast area in his bathrobe. has a bowl of cornflakes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have a seat, Billy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (he looks up) You know John Lennon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY sits. MISTER FRENCH are nearby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, he was president before Lincoln.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles) Lennon said `I'm an artist. You give me a fuckin' tuba and I'll get you something out of it'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like to squeeze some fuckin' money out of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COSTELLO and MISTER FRENCH look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smart mouth. Too bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COSTELLO lifts a piece of plastic on the table revealing severed human hand. BILLY tries to conceal his shock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: QUEENAN and STAFF SGT. DIGNAM are listening to the live broadcast. QUEENAN is benign. Lights of equipment in his specs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COSTELLO takes the ring off the finger of the severed han Partial exchange with MISTER FRENCH. BILLY watches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The point with John Lennon is a man can look at anything and make something out of it. For instance, I look at you and I think what can I use you for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (giving the hand to Mister French) Get rid of this. (back to Billy) Maybe we can work something out. Let me get dressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gets up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY runs the water in the sink. He starts to leave the bathroom and then impulsively takes off his wire and chuc it out the window as far as he can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The wire falls into the water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Queenan reacts mildly to the loss of the signal. He remov his headphones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was quick. He dead already?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A GREEK GUY (JIMMY PAPPAS) in chef's whites is cuffed and stuffed by TACTICAL OFFICERS. He has no idea what is goin on. COLIN and BARRIGAN follow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This will get Captain Ellerby on the six o'clock news.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No wonder you get ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY walking and talking on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I won't do it if I have to wear a wire. No wires. Ever, ever, you understand me? You don't know what this is like. (listens) Micro what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Queenan on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Microprocessors. We'll probably be at war with the Chinese in twenty- odd years and Costello is selling them military technology. Microprocessors, chips, computer parts. Anybody says anything about anything like that, you let us know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ELLERBY is before a thicket of microphones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you have a tip from an informant?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it was tireless police activity that ah effected ah the arrest of the ah alleged perpetrator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COLIN is rolling a quarter across the backs of his finger BROWN (last seen as Billy's friend) and BARRIGAN, new plainclothes recruits to Colin's special squad, sit acros from him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been put in charge of this unit. It is a small surveillance sub-unit but it is mine. And I didn't take this job in order to fuck it up, or to let anyone else fuck it up, whosoever they may be. I hand picked this group. You are my A-team so I want you to conduct yourselves accordingly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through glass we see ELLERBY, preening. ELLERBY gives the thumbs up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Captain. And our primary target is obviously Frank Costello. But we don't communicate with anyone else in this shop. Queenan is compartmentalizing everything in SIU. It's the right thing to do, personally I don't trust these fucking troopers either. We think we might have a problem. We think Costello's got a rat in the State Police.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.   Really.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do we have direct access to Queenan's undercovers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not happy about this) No. Ah...not presently. Not presently. But I'm hoping to get things...reorganized. That's it. Congratulations. Don't disappoint me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BROWN and BARRIGAN leave.       Colin leaves as well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Brown) I know why I'm here. I made him feel guilty. Why are you here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Intelligence and aptitude.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's new.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COLIN opens his cell phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello Dad. I have a new job. (ALT: I got a promotion.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MISTER FRENCH backhands a guy into a table of betting sli

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's your fucking license? I don't see no fucking license.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What license.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY, who is not wearing a cast anymore, watches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no such thing as a license, of course, but you definitely have to have one. (grabs the bookie by the ear) If you are not being run by us you will be run by someone else, which means you will have let undesirable elements into Mr. Costello's area.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A HARD GUY sitting reaches inside his coat. BILLY in a fl breaks his jaw with a pistol barrel and then covers the sprawled HARD GUY with the gun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (spitting teeth) I was going for my fucking cigarettes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was. They fall from his fingers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, that's Jimmy Bags. What the fuck you doin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the fuck. I didn't know....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no profit if I pay him two grand a week. I'm in the hole if I pay him two grand a week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then make more money or go out of business. This is America. If you don't make money you're a fucking douchebag. What are you going to do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Make more money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the spirit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY and MISTER FRENCH emerge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very interesting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, well. Fuck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry about it. Guy didn't need need his teeth anyway. Maybe if he was an Eskimo. But in this country we eat a variety of items.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They get into COSTELLO'S CAR. Billy in the front seat. Mi French in the back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He knocked Jimmy Bags teeth out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COSTELLO does an Edgar Kennedy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reaching for his cigarettes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay! You gonna give me shit, it wasn't no reason----he put his hand in his coat! I don't know if he's a bookie or what the fuck he's doing...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting) Well, you know what the fuck a bookie does?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Costello) Pays you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bingo. Anyway, I like a guy who goes around knocking guys teeth out for no reason.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes out a cell phone and hands it to BILLY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here. From now on call the bar and ask for Mikey. Just Mikey. You ask for Mikey because there's no Mikey. Wait. We'll call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forty-eight hours from the time this phone first rings, you take the fucking chip out - like so - and you fucking destroy it. After three days a phone ain't clean. If you use a phone which is not clean, you will have a accident. You never call us. We call you. You got that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't fuckin' hear you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lobster-bib kind of place. DAYTIME DRINKERS, MICKS in b boat shoes, hyper-aware of... COSTELLO and BILLY in a bac table. COSTELLO, having finished his lunch, is drawing. B is unused to being the subject of so many stares. He has of a coked-out nervousness, dirty hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't look. There's a white van across the parking lot?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WE see it through the smeared glass: the WHITE VAN we alw see. This time with a different magnetic business sign.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (lifting and looking at his sketch) They don't have directional microphones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What, do you got x-ray vision?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not taking his eyes off his sketch) They don't have directional microphones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY registers what seems to be inside information. COSTELLO looks over his half-glasses at Billy's untouched food. COSTELLO is sizing Billy up: has been thinking abou him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People looking at you make you self- conscious?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY shrugs. Indicating: Yeah, well, who the fuck wouldn be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why? They're minuses. They can't tell the difference between a rock star and a career criminal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyone not a criminal is a minus?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you soft? That's not what I said. Eat something, Jesus Christ, we got a nice day by the water. Sun's shining, gulls are up...Nice smell of ozone...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TWO PRIESTS and a NUN are sitting two tables over. An old priest and a younger one. COSTELLO notices. THE NUN gets and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know if your father were alive and saw you, sitting here with me, let's say he would have a word with me about this, in fact, he'd kill seven guys just to cut my throat. And he could do it, which is something you may not know about William Costigan, Sr.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He never, ah, I mean never?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He kept his own counsel. He never wanted money. You can't do a thing with a man like that. Your uncle Jackie needed a lot of money. But even though he got his money from me, he also would kill my entire fucking family if he saw me here with you. And I think about this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what are talking about here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fact is you're not a guy fresh from the zoo who wants to run a spring water distributor and I don't see you up the dog track as a general manager.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at it this way. It's like a tuba. I want to see if I can get something out of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COSTELLO smiles at this, then looks at his sketch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ever think of going back to school?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With all due respect, Mr. Costello, school's out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well that's your problem. Maybe someday you'll wake the fuck up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gets up and leaves the table, leaving BILLY sitting th COSTELLO stops to speak to the priests.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good day, Fathers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (terrified and simultaneously) Good morning [day], Francis, good morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The OLDER PRIEST is very nervous, looking around. The YOU PRIEST concerned for his elder but personally not implica COSTELLO leans over the OLDER PRIEST, a pathetic man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You recall our chat? (the OLDER PRIEST nods, terrified) "I am as God made me", was that what you said? May I remind you, God don't run the bingo in this archdiocese.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May I remind you, Mr. Costello, that pride comes before the fall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What comes before the Fall is the Summertime.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COSTELLO notices that THE NUN is heading back to the tabl

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How is Sister Mary Theresa doing? We had a tasty relationship before she took her vows. Enjoy your clams, cocksuckers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FITZY beats up a guy with a pipe.   Billy watches from th background.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FITZY and the Costello gang blow up a car as Billy watche Laughing, they hop in their vehicles and drive off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OFFICE decorated with golf implements. ELLERBY has a hangover. Sunglasses. Eating baby aspirin by the small fistful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not making enough progress with Costello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Progress" is hard to define. I make progress every day. In fact, I'm making progress now. There are guys in this department make excellent progress for twenty years without ever getting anything you could definitively call a result. It's like any American industry. Nobody minds if you don't succeed as long as you don't fuck up.

Billy doesn't use the bedroom. He sleeps on the couch amo boxes of pictures, papers, teacups wrapped in newspaper. BILLY is sitting on the couch. He reaches into a box and out photographs like cards. Scenes from his life. His for life. His family life, his life as a child, his romantic life. He sits and stares at the pictures. He rearranges t photographs in different ways.

dialogues.text: Hey.   Let's go through the routine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think you can pop someone. There's no special card to play. The guy whose jaw you broke was Boston Police Department.

dialogues.text: I'm going fuckin' nuts. I can't be someone else every day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get in the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.text: Maybe. Maybe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A clock ticking. Madolyn is looking across at ...Billy. Madolyn is very much a guarded shrink. But no one's more guarded than Billy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's like confession. Isn't it. This sort of thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People make things up in confession. You know that?

dialogues.text: I know they do.

dialogues.text: People are liars. They want to be stars of their little films.

dialogues.text: That's an interesting observation.

dialogues.text: Do you lie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm asking if you lie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honesty isn't synonymous with truth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You lie. So, is it to do some good, to get somewhere personally, or just for the fuck of it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I expect sometimes...people...do it to keep things...on an even keel.

dialogues.text: So, you had a parent who was a drunk?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (simply) No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's keep this with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.text: How do you know he was a cop?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad haircut, no dress sense and a slight air of scumbag entitlement. You see cops?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's part of what I do. Although, I don't normally see cadets who were kicked out of the Academy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should get a better job...

dialogues.text: Do they all come in and cry...your cops?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes they cry if they had trouble at home or if they've had to...use their weapons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me tell you something. They signed up to use their fuckin' weapons. Most of them. But they watch enough TV so they know they have to "weep" after they use their weapons. No one's more full of shit than a cop. Except a cop on TV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I looked through your file and I see you have a record of assault. What was it like for you in jail?

dialogues.text: You want to hear about the showers?

dialogues.text: What do you expect from coming here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to come here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know it's not elective...on your part...but, now that you're here, what do you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you lied, you'd have an easier time getting what you wanted.

dialogues.text: What's that say about what you do for a living?

dialogues.text: Madolyn is taken aback. She closes her file.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I think we better have a few more meetings before we can even talk about prescriptions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She closes his file and puts it in the rack behind her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm having panic attacks. You didn't even ask about that. Last night I thought I was having a fucking heart attack. I puked in a trash barrel on the way in here, I haven't slept for weeks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this true?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. I said something true. I want some fucking pills and you close my file? I thought I was supposed to tell the truth here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, you are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If only fuckin' here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (giving into stress) Guy comes in in pain, against every instinct of ...privacy, of, of, self reliance... that he has, and you don't help him? You send him off to score smack on the fucking street?! (Is that what you do, Mrs. Fuckin' Doctor?)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two pills.

dialogues.text: Why don't you just give me a bottle of scotch and a handgun to blow my fucking head off. Are we done here with this psychiatry bullshit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck...

You don't know what they are. Who gives a fuck? Cash will be handed over in a building which we have under AV surveillance. Staff Sergeant Sullivan's team... (he nods at COLIN) Will ID the bad guys and listen in on the phones.
